great information and for holding open doors it's a bit heavier to be
honest but highly recommend reading both and both of them contain the four golden signals
and these are traffic error latency and saturation just to confuse you
saturation means something completely different here but there we go so first
of all we have traffic how much your API is being hit within a certain amount of time so in
this case how many cars are going through my endpoint within the last one
minute this is normally pretty standard from what I can see for measuring with apis you want to see how much you're
being hit often people have a relative idea of how much they can get
hit it's useful in combination with the other three we have error
again error is particularly interesting in this case in my point of view so
Google proposed that you shouldn't just measure error but me measure it in ratio
to successful calls so error in this case could again be your
500s and your success could be your 200s for HTP status codes in this case you
want to see how many of your uh API calls are successful opposed to erroring
and that ratio should show you whether you're having problems or not most apis will have a few errors it's the way it
is but not only this the reason why I find errors particularly interesting with
apis is because they're contextual yes we have our high level
errors um such as 500 you don't want those but in certain cases something
like a 404 not found might not be considered an error it might actually be
considered successful behavior for the API depending on who's written it maybe they want that as part of their
documentation you want to consider what an erroring call means for your
API additionally it's not just a high level errors you might have errors you've written in yourself and you'll be
wanting to measure those as well errors a little bit more complex in apis than is in
services but again in combination with traffic if your traffic's going up and
suddenly your error is going up as well might be the traffic that's a problem so
we can use this to gain context of what's going on then we have
latency I couldn't come up with a good example to draw for this one but it's a time between getting a request to your
API and responding again like when we were talking about ation with Services if
that's slowing up and you don't have as much traffic as would be a problem
you've probably got a problem either with your API or a lower down service so latency in combination with
your traffic and your error can give you a great clue about what's going
on and then there's saturation not everybody can measure
saturation in this case because it requires low testing um um and I'll
explain why with this example so for this particular example your glass is
your API and the water is how much it's being hit you keep hitting it and hitting it and hitting it until it can't
cope with anymore your glass is full and this is where you're at 100%
saturation from then on you know to what percentage you're saturated so if you're
in this case I would be 30% saturated normally my API would be okay my other
half's laughing at me he's mean um but again in combination you know that your
API might not be it might be getting to that 80% and suddenly everything else is throwing errors and you've got problems
